Merrell Moab 2 Mid Gore-Tex Review: Complete Guide to the Ultimate Hiking Boot

After logging over 500 miles in my Merrell Moab 2 Mid Gore-Tex boots across diverse terrains from the rocky trails of Zion National Park to the muddy paths of Olympic rainforest, I've developed a comprehensive understanding of what makes these boots tick. This detailed review covers everything from waterproof performance to long-term durability, helping you decide if these are the right boots for your adventures. Explore National Parks brings you honest, field-tested gear reviews.

Table of Contents

  • Overview & First Impressions
  • Technical Specifications & Design
  • Trail Performance Analysis
  • My Experience & User Reviews
  • Pros and Cons
  • Frequently Asked Questions
  • Conclusion

Overview & First Impressions

The Merrell Moab 2 Mid Gore-Tex represents the evolution of one of the most successful hiking boot lines in outdoor retail history. When I first unboxed these boots, I was immediately impressed by their substantial yet not overly bulky construction. The synthetic leather and mesh upper feels robust without being stiff, and the Gore-Tex bootie construction promises reliable waterproof protection.

Quick Stats

  • Weight: 2 lbs 4 oz (pair)
  • Drop: 12mm heel-to-toe
  • Material: Synthetic leather/mesh upper
  • Waterproofing: Gore-Tex membrane
  • Price Range: $135-180

What sets the Moab 2 Mid Gore-Tex apart from its low-cut sibling is the extended ankle support, which I found invaluable during my backcountry adventures in Rocky Mountain National Park. The additional material doesn't add significant weight but provides crucial protection against ankle rolls on uneven terrain. The boot strikes an excellent balance between traditional hiking boot support and modern lightweight design philosophy.

During my initial break-in period, which lasted approximately 15-20 miles of mixed terrain hiking, I experienced minimal hot spots or pressure points. This is remarkable for a boot in this price category, where many competitors require extensive breaking-in periods. The internal volume accommodates various foot shapes well, though wide-footed hikers should definitely consider the available wide-width options.

Pro Tip from the Trail:

I discovered that the Merrell Moab 2 Gore-Tex low-cut version works perfectly for day hikes, but the mid-height version truly shines on multi-day backpacking trips where ankle protection becomes crucial. The extra coverage saved me from several potential injuries on loose scree slopes in the Grand Canyon.

Technical Specifications & Design

Upper Construction

The upper combines durable synthetic leather with breathable mesh panels strategically placed to maximize airflow while maintaining protection. The synthetic materials have proven surprisingly durable in my testing, showing minimal wear even after extensive use on abrasive granite surfaces in Yosemite. The mesh inserts provide crucial ventilation, though they're positioned to avoid high-wear areas.

Merrell's integration of the Gore-Tex membrane creates a bootie construction that's both waterproof and breathable. Unlike some competitors that use a simple Gore-Tex lining, this design creates a sealed environment around your foot while still allowing moisture vapor to escape. During humid summer hikes in the Appalachians, I noticed significantly less internal moisture buildup compared to non-breathable waterproof boots.

Sole System & Traction

The Vibram TC5+ outsole represents the heart of this boot's traction system. Through extensive testing on various surfaces – from wet granite slabs to muddy forest floors – I found the lug pattern provides reliable grip in most conditions. The 5mm lug depth strikes a good balance between traction and durability, though it's not as aggressive as some dedicated scrambling or mountaineering boots.

Comparison with Other Merrell Models

Having tested multiple Merrell models, I can attest that the Merrell Moab 3 Gore-Tex offers improved materials but at a higher price point. The Merrell Moab Speed Gore-Tex provides a more athletic feel but sacrifices some traditional boot durability. For classic hiking boot performance, the Moab 2 Mid remains my go-to recommendation.

Midsole & Cushioning

The EVA midsole provides adequate cushioning for most hiking applications, though it's not as plush as some modern trail running inspired designs. During my 18-mile day hike along the Rim Trail in Grand Canyon, I experienced some foot fatigue toward the end, suggesting that hikers planning extremely long days might want to consider aftermarket insoles for enhanced comfort.

The removable EVA footbed works well for most foot types, but I found that replacing it with a higher-quality aftermarket insole significantly improved comfort during extended wear. The internal volume accommodates various insole thicknesses without creating pressure points, making customization straightforward for users with specific comfort requirements.

Check Current Price on Amazon

Trail Performance Analysis

Waterproof Performance

The Gore-Tex membrane in the Moab 2 Mid Gore-Tex consistently delivered reliable waterproof protection throughout my testing period. During a particularly challenging hike through Olympic National Park's rainforest during a Pacific Northwest downpour, my feet remained completely dry despite hiking through multiple stream crossings and constant rain for over 6 hours.

However, I did notice that in extremely hot and humid conditions, such as summer hiking in the Southeast, the waterproof membrane can contribute to moisture buildup inside the boot. This is a common trade-off with all waterproof footwear, not specific to this model. For hot, dry conditions, hikers might consider the non-Gore-Tex version for improved breathability.

Traction & Stability

The Vibram TC5+ outsole proved its worth across diverse terrain types. On the slickrock trails of Arches National Park, the rubber compound provided confident grip on dry sandstone. During muddy conditions in the Cascade Range, the lug pattern effectively shed debris and maintained traction on slippery surfaces.

Where I noticed some limitations was on wet granite and polished rock surfaces common in the Sierra Nevada. While not dangerous, the traction wasn't quite as confidence-inspiring as more aggressive lug patterns found on technical hiking boots. For general trail hiking, however, the traction performance exceeded my expectations.

Long-Distance Comfort

Over my 500+ miles of testing, comfort remained consistently good, though not exceptional. The boot excels in the crucial first 10-15 miles of any hike, providing solid support and cushioning. Beyond this distance, I began to notice some pressure points, particularly around the forefoot during long descents. This suggests the boot is optimized for day hiking and shorter backpacking trips rather than extended thru-hiking applications.

Durability Observations

After extensive use, I've noticed some wear patterns worth mentioning. The synthetic leather upper has held up remarkably well, showing only minor scuffing in high-abrasion areas. The Vibram outsole shows normal wear patterns, with approximately 1-2mm of lug wear after 500 miles of mixed terrain. Some users report premature sole separation issues, though I haven't experienced this personally. For comparison, similar durability can be expected from the Merrell Moab 3 Mid Gore-Tex with slightly improved materials.

Women's Version Men's Version

My Experience & User Reviews

My Personal Trail Experience

During my first major test of these boots – a 4-day backpacking trip through Glacier National Park – I gained invaluable insights into their real-world performance. The Moab 2 Mid Gore-Tex handled the varied conditions brilliantly, from early morning dew-soaked meadows to afternoon thundershowers and rocky alpine terrain.

What impressed me most was the boot's versatility. On day one, crossing numerous streams along the Highline Trail, the waterproofing proved absolutely reliable. Day two brought long climbs on loose scree, where the ankle protection prevented several potential injuries. By day three, hiking on established trails with a full pack, the support and comfort remained consistent despite accumulated fatigue.

The ranger at Logan Pass mentioned that the Moab series has been the most recommended boot among park staff for general hiking, citing its reliable performance and reasonable price point. This real-world endorsement from professionals who see hundreds of hikers daily carries significant weight in my assessment.

User Review Summary

Positive Review - Bill (REI)

6 months use, Red River Gorge

"Never have I had a better experience than this past one when I bought these shoes. We received over an inch and a half of rain, but it was no issue for these shoes. I accidentally submerged them a few times while performing run-off creek crossings, and my feet remained dry."

★★★★★ Highly Recommends

Mixed Review - Randy S (REI)

Size 10W, 200 miles use

"These shoes are comfortable, have decent traction, live up to the waterproof promise, and hike pretty well. But their durability is questionable. I've put a couple hundred miles of trail hiking on them and the soles are starting to delaminate."

★★★☆☆ Does Not Recommend

Positive Review - Huskyhiker (REI)

Comparison with winter version

"First, they were so comfortable right out of the box, I didn't need to break them in at all. They are very lite weight and breathable. They are very good, but could be better. Outstanding cushion and shock absorption."

★★★★☆ Recommends

Seasonal Performance Notes

Through testing across different seasons, I've identified some key performance characteristics. Spring hiking in the Pacific Northwest, where stream crossings and muddy conditions are common, represents ideal conditions for the Moab 2 Mid Gore-Tex. The waterproofing excels, and the moderate insulation level prevents overheating during active hiking.

Summer use in desert environments like Death Valley revealed the limitations of Gore-Tex in extreme heat. While the boots remained functionally sound, internal heat buildup became noticeable during long exposure to direct sunlight and high ambient temperatures. For hot climate hiking, consider the breathable versions from the Moab 2 Mid series.

View Similar Models on Amazon

Pros and Cons

Advantages

  • Reliable Waterproofing: Gore-Tex membrane consistently keeps feet dry in wet conditions
  • Excellent Value: Premium features at a reasonable price point compared to competitors
  • Quick Break-in: Comfortable from the first hike with minimal adjustment period
  • Versatile Performance: Handles diverse terrain types and conditions effectively
  • Good Ankle Support: Mid-height design provides protection without weight penalty
  • Wide Width Options: Available in multiple widths for better fit customization

Disadvantages

  • Durability Concerns: Some users report premature sole separation after moderate use
  • Hot Weather Limitations: Gore-Tex can cause overheating in extreme heat and humidity
  • Limited Cushioning: EVA midsole adequate but not exceptional for long distances
  • Traction Limitations: Not ideal for technical scrambling or very aggressive terrain
  • Weight: Heavier than modern lightweight hiking shoes and trail runners
  • Style Options: Limited color choices compared to fashion-forward competitors

Bottom Line Assessment

The Merrell Moab 2 Mid Gore-Tex represents a solid, traditional approach to hiking footwear. While it may not have the cutting-edge features or ultra-lightweight design of newer models like the Moab 3 Mid Gore-Tex, it delivers consistent, reliable performance at an accessible price point.

For hikers seeking proven reliability over bleeding-edge innovation, these boots remain an excellent choice. The durability concerns, while worth noting, don't affect all units and may be related to specific manufacturing batches or usage patterns. Overall, the benefits significantly outweigh the drawbacks for most hiking applications.

Compare Prices & Reviews

Frequently Asked Questions

Are Merrell Moab 2 Mid Gore-Tex boots truly waterproof?

Yes, the Merrell Moab 2 Mid Gore-Tex boots feature genuine Gore-Tex membrane technology that provides reliable waterproof protection. In my extensive field testing across various terrains and weather conditions, these boots consistently kept my feet dry during stream crossings, wet trail conditions, and light rain. However, like all Gore-Tex footwear, prolonged submersion or damage to the upper materials can compromise waterproofing. The breathable membrane also helps prevent overheating while maintaining water resistance, though this balance becomes challenging in extremely hot and humid conditions.

How does the Moab 2 Mid compare to the newer Moab 3 and Speed 2 models?

The Moab 2 Mid represents the tried-and-true classic design with proven durability and comfort. Compared to the Moab 3, it offers similar performance but with slightly less refined materials and construction. The Speed 2 model is lighter and more athletic, featuring improved breathability and a more modern design, but may sacrifice some traditional hiking boot robustness. For traditional hiking and proven reliability, the Moab 2 Mid remains an excellent choice, especially considering its typically lower price point and widespread availability in various widths.

What size should I order for the Moab 2 Mid Gore-Tex?

Based on user feedback and my personal experience, the Moab 2 Mid Gore-Tex runs fairly true to size, though many hikers recommend going up half a size for longer hikes to accommodate foot swelling and thick hiking socks. The boot offers medium width as standard, with wide options available for those with broader feet. I suggest trying them on in the afternoon when your feet are naturally more swollen, and always test with the type of hiking socks you'll actually wear on the trail. For reference, I normally wear size 10.5 in athletic shoes and found the 10.5 Medium width perfect for day hikes, with 11 being better for multi-day trips.

Conclusion

After extensive testing across diverse environments and conditions, the Merrell Moab 2 Mid Gore-Tex earns my recommendation as a reliable, versatile hiking boot for the majority of outdoor enthusiasts. While it may not be the lightest or most technically advanced option available, it delivers consistent performance, proven durability, and excellent value in a package that works well for most hiking applications.

The waterproof protection proved reliable throughout my testing, the comfort remained consistent across hundreds of miles, and the construction quality met expectations for this price range. The reported durability concerns, while worth monitoring, didn't affect my test pair and may be related to specific usage patterns or manufacturing variations.

For hikers seeking a traditional, no-nonsense approach to trail footwear, these boots represent an excellent entry point into serious hiking gear. They're particularly well-suited for day hiking, weekend backpacking, and general outdoor activities where reliable performance matters more than cutting-edge features.

Who Should Consider These Boots

Ideal For:

  • • Day hikers and weekend backpackers
  • • Hikers in wet climates and seasons
  • • Those seeking reliable, proven performance
  • • Budget-conscious outdoor enthusiasts
  • • Wide-footed hikers needing width options

Consider Alternatives If:

  • • You prioritize ultralight weight above all
  • • Primary hiking in hot, dry climates
  • • Need technical scrambling performance
  • • Prefer cutting-edge materials and design
  • • Planning extensive thru-hiking trips

Final Recommendation

The Merrell Moab 2 Mid Gore-Tex stands as a testament to the value of evolutionary rather than revolutionary design. It takes a proven platform and refines it to meet the needs of modern hikers while maintaining the reliability that made the Moab series famous.

For most hikers, these boots will serve admirably across a wide range of conditions and applications. The combination of waterproof protection, reasonable weight, solid construction, and competitive pricing makes them a smart choice for building a reliable outdoor kit.

While newer models like the Women's Moab 3 Mid Gore-Tex offer incremental improvements, the Moab 2 Mid remains relevant and valuable, especially for hikers who prioritize proven performance over the latest features.
